name: Femme fatales to fembots
description: When women gain power, men get scared. You can see this in the mysterious, seductive and deadly femme fatale. Using her sexuality and intellect to manipulate, control and co-opt power, the femme fatale reflects prevailing attitudes to women.

start.title: Metropolis
start.creator_credit: Fritz Lang, Erich Pommer and UFA
start.brief_description: A classic early SF story of a dehumanised futuristic society in which the workers toil below the ground for the benefit of an elite who live above. Fascinating sequences are woven into the sentimental story of the romance between the son of the city’s ruler and a saintly girl from below ground.

constellations_other.name: Hiding in plain sight
constellations_other.description: This print of upside-down heads is an early optical illusion featuring hidden characters. Movie studios have continued the tradition of playing with perspective in the bold designs, vivid colours and hidden meanings of film posters.

end.title: Ex Machina
end.creator_credit: Allon Reich, Andrew Macdonald and Andrew MacDonald
end.brief_description: A young coder wins a competition to spend a week at a private mountain retreat belonging to the world’s largest internet company’s reclusive CEO. But when he arrives, Caleb has to participate in an experiment involving the world’s first true AI.

constellations_other.name: Dream A Little Crazy: The next stage of human evolution
constellations_other.description: Collaborators Lucy McRae and Rachel Wingfield created a ‘biological bakery’ for Architecture In Helsinki’s "Dream A Little Crazy". Manufacturing a series of mass-produced band members the clip explores speculative science and the future of the human body’s evolution.

constellations_other.name: Arcades and AI
constellations_other.description: Using the godfather of computing, Alan Turing, as a starting point, this Constellation traces the evolution of AI representation on-screen and the way female androids, robots and holograms have been hyper sexualised.

constellations_other.name: Robots, robots everywhere
constellations_other.description: Steampunk aesthetics, malevolent AI and cybernetic cops push the frontiers of imagination in this Constellation inspired by Dishonored 2.

links.description: The sexual and dangerous ‘fembot’ trope is seen throughout cinematic history, from Maria in Metropolis to Pris (Darryl Hannah) in Blade Runner to Ava (Alicia Vikander) in Ex-Machina.

start.title: Fatal attraction
start.creator_credit: Adrian Lyne, Sherry Lansing, Stanley R. Jaffe and Paramount Pictures
start.brief_description: Michael Douglas, Glenn Close and Anne Archer star in this gripping, if at times inconsistent thriller. A passionate week-end encounter ends Dan Gallagher’s perfect life. Alex refuses to be a woman scorned and her capacity for revenge and violence is without limit. The conclusion is unforgettably shattering as the nightmare draws to its inevitable “bloody” climax. Glenn Close gives an excellent, terrifying performance as the homicidal Alex as the film grapples with men’s subconscious fears about women.

links.description: The opera Madame Butterfly is the soundtrack to Alex’s (Close) affair with a married man. The ‘Butterfly’ is a trope of a subservient woman, which Anna May Wong played in The Toll of the Sea. She’s famous for playing ‘dragon ladies’ similar to the femme fatale.

end.title: Weird science
end.creator_credit: John Hughes, Joel Silver and Universal Pictures
end.brief_description: John Hughes wrote and and directed this teen farce. Gary and Wyatt are two unpopular geeks in high school who fantasise about having beautiful girlfriends and being the coolest kids in school. Inspired by a clip from the classic film “Frankenstein”, the two decide to try their luck at creating the woman of their dreams. The result is Lisa - beautiful, saucy and the answer to every man’s dream - who becomes a mentor to the two libidinous youths, her mission being to help them get the young women they want. Cast includes: Anthony Michael Hall, Kelly LeBrock, Ilan Mitchell-Smith, Robert Downey Jr. and Bill Paxton.

links.description: Robotic women often represent men’s desire to control women and reduce them to literal objects. In the 1980s two ‘nerds’ gain popularity when they use computers to create ‘the perfect woman’, who ends up teaching them to respect women.

end.title: The Maltese falcon
end.creator_credit: John Huston, Henry Blanke and Warner Bros Pictures
end.brief_description: In this classic Humphrey Bogart film noir, John Huston sketches a dark, cynical world with painfully deep perception. Sam Spade, Dashiell Hammett’s archetypal private eye, is caught in the desperate search for the jewelled falcon of Malta. Spade’s pursuit of his partner’s killer leads him to a group of individuals who want the black bird: Brigid O’Shaughnessey (Mary Astor), the beautiful femme fatale, cowardly Joel Cairo (Peter Lorre) and pompously inflated Kasper Gutman (Sydney Greenstreet) and as the falcon comes within their reach their intense greed is sharply etched. Huston also wrote the script.

links.description: A Fool There Was’ sexual ‘vampire’ was a threat to traditional gender roles of the era. So was the femme fatale, who appeared in 1940s cinema after women gained independence during WWII. Mary Astor’s character in The Maltese Falcon was one of the first.

end.title: 102 dalmatians
end.creator_credit: Kevin Lima, Edward S. Feldman and Walt Disney Pictures
end.brief_description: Based on the novel by Dodie Smith, and a sequel to Disney’s 1996 live-action adaptation of their animated classic, ‘101 Dalmatians’, this live-action film once again features Glenn Close in the role of the over-the-top and rather bizarre Cruella De Vil. After three years in prison Cruella is determined to keep away from animal fur - especially of the doggy kind - but it seems despite all her best intentions, Cruella unwittingly finds herself again embroiled in a ‘haute couture’ situation. Cast includes Ioan Gruffudd, Alice Evans, Tim McInnerny, Ian Richardson, Gerard Depardieu.

links.description: The dragon lady is a deceitful, domineering and hyper-sexualised character that exoticised East Asian women. Wong’s role in Daughter of the Dragon made it famous and now it’s a visual shorthand for dangerous, powerful women, as seen in Glen Close’s costume from 102 Dalmatians.
